{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox monastery | name = Cong Abbey
''Cúnga Fheichín'' | image = CongAbbey07.JPG | caption = View of the remains of Cong Abbey | order = [[Augustinian]] | founder = [[Saint Feichin]] | established = 7th century (original structure), 12th century | disestablished = 1542 | mother = | diocese = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Tuam|Archdiocese of Tuam]] | churches = | people = | heritage_designation = [[National Monument (Ireland)|National Monument]] | style = early Gothic | location = Cong, County Mayo, Ireland | coordinates = {{coord|53|32|25|N|9|17|12|W|region:IE_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | map_type = Ireland | remains = church building, cloisters, monks' fishing house | public_access = yes }} '''Cong Abbey''' also known as the Royal Abbey of Cong, is a historic site located at [[Cong (Mayo)|Cong]], on the borders of counties [[County Galway|Galway]] and [[County Mayo|Mayo]], in [[Ireland]]'s province of [[Connacht]]. The ruins of the former [[Augustinians|Augustinian]] abbey mostly date to the 13th century and have been described as featuring some of finest examples of medieval ecclesiastical architecture in Ireland. ==History== In the early 7th century, a church was built at this site, reportedly by [[Saint Feichin]]. A later building was destroyed by fire in 1114. Within the next twenty years or so, [[Tairrdelbach Ua Conchobair|Turlough Mor O’Connor]], the [[High King of Ireland]], refounded the abbey. Raiders from [[Munster]] destroyed the buildings in 1137 but they were rebuilt by King Turlough.{{cite web|url= http://www.mayolibrary.ie/en/LocalStudies/IrishTouristAssociationSurvey/CongandTheNeale/CongAbbey/PDFDocument,16111,en.pdf|title=Irish Tourist Association Survey of 1945: Cong Abbey|publisher=Mayo County Library| date= |first= |last= |accessdate=22 May 2013}} The Abbey was refounded as an [[Augustinians|Augustinian]] settlement in 1138. It was one of the earliest Augustinian settlements south of [[Armagh]] which was founded in 1126.{{Cite book|title=Around and About Cong|last=Robert|first=Scott|publisher=Kinlough Press|year=2017|location=Cong|pages=11}} In 1198, his son, [[Ruaidrí Ua Conchobair]] (Rory O'Connor), Ireland's last High King, constructed new buildings and also lived the last 15 years of his life at the abbey.[[William Wilde|Sir W. Wilde]] ''Lough Corrib'', p. 181. He died here and was reportedly briefly buried in the abbey before being exhumed and re-interred at [[Clonmacnoise]]. Cong Abbey was also closely associated with the [[Duffy (surname)|O'Duffy family]] at least from 1097 to 1501. The [[Annals of the Four Masters]] record that in 1150, [[Muireadhach Ua Dubhthaigh]], [[Archbishop]] of [[Connacht]], died at Cong aged 75. {{cite web|url= http://celt.ucc.ie/publishd.html|title=Annals of the Four Masters at Corpus of Electronic Texts (CELT)|publisher=UCC| date= |first= |last= |accessdate=22 April 2014}} His name is inscribed upon the processional [[Cross of Cong]].[[Margaret Stokes|Stokes, Margaret]]. Early Christian Art in Ireland. Part 1. London: Chapman and Hall Limited, 1887–1894 The [[Normans|Norman]] knight, [[William de Burgh]], attacked Cong in 1203, and again the abbey was rebuilt.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} In the 1307 the abbey was reconstructed and dedicated to [[St Mary]]. Cong Abbey was suppressed sometime after 1542 and later fell into ruins. The last (nominal) abbot was Father [[Patrick Prendergast (abbot)|Patrick Prendergast]], parish priest of Cong from 1795 until his death in 1829. He was the preserver of the [[Cross of Cong]]. After his death, the cross was bought by [[James MacCullagh]] for the [[Royal Irish Academy]]. The first restoration of the abbey was started by [[Benjamin Guinness]] in 1855, soon after he had bought nearby [[Ashford Castle]] in 1852.{{cite web|url= http://www.congtourism.com/cngabbey.htm |title=Cong Abbey|publisher=Cong Tourism| date= |first= |last= |accessdate=22 May 2013}} ==Architecture== The remains of Cong Abbey have been praised as featuring some of the finest examples of early gothic architecture and masonry in Ireland. The present church, and possibly the fragmentary cloister where the monks worked and prayed, belong to the rebuilding of the early 13th century. The north doorway of the church, and the elaborate doorways that open onto the cloister from the east range of the monastery, may pre-date the attack by William de Burgo. The doorway with two fine windows on either side belongs to the chapter house, where the monastery’s daily business was conducted as well as a chapter of the [[Augustinians#The Augustinian Rule|rule]] being read each day. This was also where the community gathered to confess their sins publicly. The sculpture in the abbey, which is some of the finest in Ireland, suggests links to French styles of the period.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} The grounds of the abbey also contain a monks’ fishing house, probably built in the 15th or 16th century,{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} on an island in the River Cong leading towards nearby [[Lough Corrib]]. The house is built on a platform of stones over a small arch which allows the river to flow underneath the floor. There is a trapdoor in the floor in which the fish may have been kept fresh. According to local tradition, a line was connected from the fishing house to the monastery kitchen to alert the cook to fresh fish. ==Today== Cong Abbey is a national monument in the care of the [[Office of Public Works|Commissioners for Public Works]]. ==Gallery== File:NorthDoorwayCongAbbey.JPG|The North doorway File:CongCloisters.JPG|Cong Abbey cloisters File:MonksFishingHouse.JPG|Monks' Fishing House File:Monk_fishhouse_640x480.jpg|Monks' Fishing House Closeup File:RoryO’ConnorDoorway.JPG|Doorway in Cong Abbey grounds with carving of Rory O’Connor File:Rory_O'Connor_Stone_Carving.jpg|Closeup of stone carving of Rory O’Connor File:Cong Abbey 0344.jpg ==See also== * [[List of abbeys and priories in Ireland#County Mayo|List of abbeys and priories in Ireland (County Mayo)]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{commons category}} ==External links== * [http://www.galway.net/galwayguide/history/wrwilde/chapter7/abbey.html Cong Abbey in the online version of [[William Wilde]]'s book on Lough Corrib] [[Category:7th-century establishments in Ireland]] [[Category:Augustinian monasteries in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Cong, County Mayo|Abbey]] [[Category:Islands of County Mayo]] [[Category:Medieval architecture]] [[Category:Monasteries dissolved under the Irish Reformation]] [[Category:National Monuments in County Mayo]] [[Category:Religion in County Mayo]] [[Category:Ruins in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:River islands of Ireland]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in County Mayo]]

[[File:Flea circus.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.8|The flea circus of Maxfield Rubbish, San Diego, CA (2009)]] A '''flea circus''' is a [[circus (performing art)|circus]] [[sideshow]] attraction in which [[flea]]s are attached (or appear to be attached) to miniature carts and other items, and encouraged to perform circus acts within a small housing.
== History == [[File:The Go-As-You-Please Race, as seen through a Magnifying Glass.jpg|thumb|upright=1.8|"The Go-As-You-Please Race, as seen through a Magnifying Glass", engraved by J. G. Francis, from an article by [[Charles Frederick Holder|C. F. Holder]] in ''[[St. Nicholas Magazine]]'', 1886]]
The first records of flea performances were from [[watchmaker]]s who were demonstrating their metalworking skills. In 1578, Mark Scaliot produced a lock and chain that were attached to a flea. The first recorded flea circus dates back to the early 1820s, when an Italian impresario called Louis Bertolotto advertised an “extraordinary exhibition of industrious fleas” on [[Regent Street]], [[London]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Lawton |first=Graham |last2= |first2= |date=22 December 2012|title=Fleadom or death: Reviving the glorious flea circus |journal=New Scientist |publisher=Reed Business Information Ltd. |volume= |issue=2896 |pages= |doi= }}</ref> Some flea circuses persisted in very small venues in the United States as late as the 1960s. The flea circus at [[Belle Vue Zoological Gardens]], Manchester, England, was still operating in 1970. At least one genuine flea circus still performs (at the annual [[Oktoberfest]] in Munich, Germany<ref name="Birk">{{cite web|url=http://www.flohcirkus.de/geschichte |title=Geschichte |publisher=Flohcirkus.de |date= |accessdate=2013-10-25}}</ref>) and Svensons in the UK occasionally use real fleas, but most flea circuses are a sideline of magicians and clowns, and use electrical or mechanical effects instead of real fleas.
== Techniques with real fleas ==
Fleas typically live only for a few months and are not trained.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} Fleas are observed to see if they have a predisposition for jumping or walking. Once sorted, they are harnessed by carefully wrapping a thin gold wire around their neck.<ref name="natgeo">''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'', May 1988.</ref> Once in the harness, the fleas usually stay in it for life. The harnesses are attached to the props and the strong legs of the flea allow them to move objects significantly larger than themselves. Jumping fleas are used for kicking small lightweight balls. They are carefully given a ball; when they try to jump away (which is not possible because of the harness), they shoot the ball instead. Running fleas can pull small carts and vehicles or rotate a [[Ferris wheel]].<ref>Hund, Katze, Maus. 10 February 2010 VOX</ref>
There are historical reports of fleas glued to the base of the flea circus enclosure. Miniature musical instruments were then glued to the flea performers and the enclosure was heated. The fleas fought to escape, giving the impression of playing instruments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noonco.com/flea/faq.htm |title=Flea-Circus.com |publisher=Noonco.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-26}}</ref>
== Techniques without real fleas ==
Some flea circuses may appear to use real fleas, but in fact do not. A variety of electrical, magnetic, and mechanical devices have been used to augment exhibits. In some cases, these mechanisms are responsible for all of the "acts", with loose fleas in the exhibit maintaining the illusion. These circuses are known as "Humbug" flea circuses. [[Michael Bentine]] gave a mechanical flea circus a regular slot on his television show, ''[[It's a Square World]]'' in the 1960s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/2LF04Y9n5hJTHK1l6ffLhPc/the-rise-and-demise-of-the-flea-circus |title=The rise and demise of the flea circus |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=BBC Radio4 |publisher=BBC |access-date=19 December 2015}}</ref> In much the same way that viewers know that a woman will not actually be [[Sawing a woman in half|cut in half]], the magician's showmanship allows viewers to [[Suspension of disbelief|suspend disbelief]] in order to enjoy the show.
== Performers == [[File:Fleas in dresses at Ye Olde Curiosity Shop.jpg|thumb|upright=1.8|Fleas in dresses at Ye Olde Curiosity Shop]]
Current flea circuses: * Professor A.G. Gertsacov's Acme Miniature Flea Circus has been touring the United States and Canada since 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trainedfleas.com|title=Acme Flea Circus Page--TrainedFleas.com!|website=www.trainedfleas.com}}</ref> * Svensons have been performing in the UK since 1999 and also make flea circuses for other entertainers. www.svensons.co.uk * Swami Bill's Flea Circus is featured at the Denver County Fair.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denvercountyfair.org/#!special-events/c457|title=Denver County Fair - Denver's own fairly weird County Fair at the National Western Complex|website=www.denvercountyfair.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://westerngardeners.com/flea-circus-is-a-must-see-at-denver-county-fair.html|title=Flea Circus is a Must See at Denver County Fair|first=Jodi|last=Torpey|date=August 8, 2013|access-date=December 7, 2015}}</ref> * Professor B's Flea Circus has been performing in Northern California, USA for the last few years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playland-not-at-the-beach.org/entertainer_bio_prof_b_01.html |title=Professor B's Flea Circus |publisher=Playland-Not-At-The-Beach |date= |accessdate=2010-08-26}}</ref> * The Flohcircus Birk at the Munich Oktoberfest in Germany.<ref name="Birk" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://munich.mydestinationinfo.com/en/oktoberfest-fun-rides |title=Oktoberfest Fun Rides |publisher=Munich.mydestinationinfo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303081945/http://munich.mydestinationinfo.com/en/oktoberfest-fun-rides |archivedate=2011-03-03 |df= }}</ref> * Professor Humbug’s Flea Circus performing at Seattle's famous Pike's Place Market.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gallery.passion4art.com/members/puppeteer/index.html|title=Puppets and Masks by Rob D'Arc|website=gallery.passion4art.com}}</ref>
In the 1990s, [[María Fernanda Cardoso]] toured the world with her [[installation art]] flea circus.<ref name="FullertonOlsson2004">{{cite book|author1=John Fullerton|author2=Jan Olsson|title=Allegories of Communication: Intermedial Concerns from Cinema to the Digital|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ABf4XCG4Hz0C&pg=PA288|year=2004|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=978-0-86196-651-6|pages=288}}</ref>
Professor Heckler's flea circus (in residence at Hubert's Dime Museum in [[Times Square]], New York until 1957) can be seen in the background of the films ''[[The Thief (1952 film)|The Thief]]'' and ''[[Easy Rider]]''. L. Bertolotto ran a famous flea circus in [[Regent Street]], London.<ref name="BertoNote">[[#BERTO2|L.Bertolotto The history of the flea]]</ref>
==In popular culture == {{main|Flea circuses in popular culture}}
Flea circuses have [[Flea circuses in popular culture|featured in cartoons, films, television shows, music, and novels]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koerferfilm.com/e/flohzirkus.html |title=Thomas Koerfer filmography – The Death of a Flea Circus Director |publisher=Koerferfilm.com |date= |accessdate=2010-09-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barbican.org.uk/music/event-detail.asp?ID=11762 |title=Trumpet Warriors: Flea Circus |publisher=Barbican |date=2011-03-03 |accessdate=2013-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193838/http://www.barbican.org.uk/music/event-detail.asp?ID=11762 |archivedate=2013-10-29 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/fifi-the-flea-mt0003246389 |title=Fifi the Flea – The Hollies | Listen, Appearances, Song Review |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-10-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Kast |first=Marlise |url=http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/media/San-Diego-Magazine/February-2008/Calendar/index.php?cparticle=2&siarticle=1 |title=Calendar – San Diego Magazine – February 2008 – San Diego, California |publisher=San Diego Magazine |date= |accessdate=2010-09-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110916153352/http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/media/San-Diego-Magazine/February-2008/Calendar/index.php?cparticle=2&siarticle=1 |archivedate=2011-09-16 |df= }}</ref>

{{Infobox artist | name = François-Léon Benouville | image = Francois leon benouville.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different than name --> | birth_date = 30 March 1821 | birth_place = [[Paris]] | death_date = 16 February 1859 | death_place = [[Paris]] | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = | residence = | education = [[École des Beaux-Arts]] | alma_mater = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | movement = Neoclassical, [[Orientalism|Orientalist]] | spouse = | partner = | awards = [[Prix de Rome]] (1845); Prix de Beaux Arts (1845) with [[Alexandre Cabanel]] | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | module = }} '''François-Léon Benouville''' ([[Paris]] 30 March 1821 – 16 February 1859 [[Paris]]) was a French painter noted for his Neoclassical religious compositions and for painting Orientalist subjects.
==Life and career== Léon Benouville first studied with his elder brother, [[Jean-Achille Benouville]] (1815–1891), in the studio of [[François-Edouard Picot]] before he transferred to [[École des Beaux-Arts]] in 1837. Like his brother he received the [[Prix de Rome]] in 1845.
Both he and his brother travelled to Rome. In Rome, as a Prix de Rome pensionary at the [[Villa Medici]]. He remained there for a year, but his brother stayed on for two more years. His works produced in Rome are influenced by early Christianity and often show representations of antiquity.
==Work and style== [[Image:Leon Benouville The Wrath of Achilles.jpg|thumb|200px|''The Wrath of [[Achilles]]'', by François-Léon Benouville ([[Musée Fabre]])]] Benouville was best known for his portraits, mythological and religious compositions in the Neoclassical and Orientalist style. He worked in oils, ink and chalk.
==Awards, prizes and honours== In 1845, Benouville, together with contemporary [[Alexandre Cabanel]], was the recipient the Prix de Beaux Arts for his painting, ''Jesus at the Pretorium.''<ref>GLUECKAPRIL, G., [ART REVIEW] "After the Fad: A Salon Favorite Now Forgotten," [Review of ''Training an Artist: Alexandre Cabanel and the Academic Process in 19th-Century France'' Dahesh Museum, ''New York Times, 3 April-13 June 1998], 3 April 1998, Online: https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/03/arts/art-review-after-the-fad-a-salon-favorite-now-forgotten.html?mcubz=3]</ref>
==Select list of paintings== * ''Portrait of Leconte de Floris'' 1840 * ''Melancholy'' c. 1843 * ''Esther'' 1844 * ''The Mockery of Christ'' 1845 * ''The Wrath of Achilles'' 1847 * ''Christian Martyrs enter the Amphitheatre,'' c.1855

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} [[File:Gcina Mhlope 5.jpg|thumb|Gcina Mhlophe at the ''Festival Internacional de Poesía de Medellín'' in 2016]] '''Nokugcina Elsie Mhlophe''' (born 24 October 1958 <ref> [http://www.sahistory.org.za/this_day/24/10 This Day in History | South African History Online ] </ref> ) is a well-known [[South Africa]]n [[anti-apartheid activist]], actress, [[storytelling|storyteller]], poet, playwright, director and author. Storytelling is a deeply traditional activity in Africa and Mhlophe is one of the few woman storytellers in a country dominated by males. She does her work through charismatic performances, working to preserve storytelling as a means of keeping history alive and encouraging South African children to read. She tells her stories in four of South Africa's languages: English, [[Afrikaans]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]] and [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]].
==Life and career== Gcina was born in 1958 in [[KwaZulu-Natal]] to a [[Xhosa people|Xhosa]] mother and a [[Zulu people|Zulu]] father. She started her working life as a domestic servant, later working as a newsreader at the [[Press Trust]] and [[BBC Radio]], then as a writer for ''[[Learn and Teach]]'', a magazine for newly-literate people.
She began to get a sense of the demand for stories while in Chicago in 1988. She performed at a library in a mostly-black neighbourhood, where an ever-growing audience kept inviting her back. Still, Mhlophe only began to think of storytelling as a career after meeting an [[Imbongi]], one of the legendary poets of African folklore, and after encouragement by [[Mannie Manim]], the then-director of the [[Market Theatre (Johannesburg)|Market Theatre]], [[Johannesburg]].
Since then Mhlophe has appeared in theatres from [[Soweto]] to London and much of her work has been translated into [[German language|German]], French, Italian, [[Swahili language|Swahili]] and Japanese. Mhlophe has travelled extensively in Africa and other parts of the world giving storytelling workshops.
Mhlophe's stories meld folklore, information, current affairs, song and [[idiom]]. The realisation of her dreams is a visceral motivator for her and she is passing on her infectious enthusiasm by developing young talent to carry forward the work of storytelling through the [[Zanendaba]] (''Bring me a story'') Initiative. This initiative, established in 2002, is a collaboration with the Market Theatre and [[READ Educational Trust|READ]], a national literacy organization.
Mhlophe currently serves as the patron of the ASSITEJ South Africa, the International Association for Theatre for Children and Young People.
Mhlophe currently serves as the patron of [[ASSITEJ]] South Africa, the International Association for Theatre for Children and Young People.
'''Selected works''' * 1983, took the lead in ''Umongikazi: The Nurse'', by [[Maishe Maponya]] * 1984, acted in ''Black Dog: Inj'emnyama'' * 1986, ''Place of Weeping'' (film) * 1986, ''Have You Seen Zandile?'' (autobiographical play, at the Market Theatre, Johannesburg, Mhlophe as Zandile) * 1987, ''Born in the RSA'' (New York) * 1989, storytelling festival at the Market Theatre (there have been many since then) * 1989, performed a praise poem in honour of Nokukhanya Luthuli, 1961 Nobel Peace Prize winner * 1990, performed ''Have You Seen Zandile?'' at the Edinburgh Festival * Toured ''Have You Seen Zandile?'' through Europe and the USA * 1989–1990, resident director at the Market Theatre, Johannesburg * co-ordinator at READ, a national literacy organization * 1991, Ashoka Fellowship (social entrepreneurship innovator) * 1993, ''Music for Little People'' (CD) * 1993, reader voice ''Not so fast, Songololo'' (videorecording), Weston Woods, Weston CT, Scholastic [http://teacher.scholastic.com/products/westonwoods/study_guides/not_so_fast_tsongololo.pdf] * 1994, ''The Gift of the Tortoise'' (contributed to the [[Ladysmith Black Mambazo]] album) * 1997, Poetry Africa, presenting poet * 1999, guest speaker at the Perth Writers Festival * Philharmonic Orchestra (London) * Royal Albert Hall (London) * Cologne Philharmonie, ''Africa at the Opera'' * Honorary doctorate from the London Open University * Honorary doctorate from the University of Natal * Lectureships at various universities * 2000, performed in ''Peter und der Wolf'' at the Komische Oper (Berlin) * Wrote music for her SABC TV series ''Gcina & Friends'' * 2002, ''Fudukazi's Magic'' screened in Durban at the African Union Film Festival * 2002, ''The Bones of Memory'' (performance, history-telling from the old and new South Africa) * 2003, lectured on storytelling at the ''Eye of the Beholder'' seminar * 2003, ''Mata Mata'' (performance, family musical) * 2006, FIFA World Cup South African handover ceremony, Germany
==Collaborations== * [[Pops Mohamed]], musician and tribal music preservationist * [[Ladysmith Black Mambazo]], choir group, ''The Gift of the Tortoise'' (CD), 1994 and ''Music for Little People in America'' (CD), 1993 * [[Bheki Khoza]], guitarist, ''Animated Tales of the World'' (TV series for Right Angle in the UK and for the SABC) * [[Anant Singh]], video producer, ''Fudukazi's Magic'' (CD and video for German audiences) * [[Biblionef South Africa]], a children's book donation agency, supplies book packages for Mhlophe's workshops, 2003
==Documentary appearances== * Acted and narrated in '' Travelling Songs'' * 1990, performed poetry in ''Songolo: voices of change'' (how aspects of culture in South Africa have become part of the anti-apartheid struggle) * 1993, ''The Travelling Song'' (the contemporary process of story gathering) * Appeared in ''Literacy Alive'' * Appeared in ''Art Works''
==Awards== * Nominee for the Noma Award for ''Queen of the Tortoises'', 1991 * Book Chat Award for ''Molo Zoleka'' * OBIE Theatrical Award (New York) for ''Born in the RSA''<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/index/1987/|title =The New York Obies Awards|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20150325120342/http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/index/1987/|archive-date =25 March 2015|dead-url =yes|df =dmy-all}}</ref> * Fringe First Award (Edinburgh) for ''Have you seen Zandile?'' * Joseph Jefferson Award for Best Actress (Chicago) for ''Have you seen Zandile?'' * Sony Award for Radio Drama from BBC Radio Africa for ''Have you seen Zandile?'' * In 2016 she was chosen as one of [[100 Women (BBC)|BBC's 100 Women]]<ref name=list2016>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-38012048 "BBC 100 Women 2016: Who is on the list?"], BBC News, 21 November 2016. Retrieved 24 November 2016.</ref>

'''GUND''' is a Canadian-owned manufacturer of [[Stuffed toy|plush stuffed animals]]. The company is based in Edison, New Jersey, and distributes throughout the United States and Canada as well as in Europe, Japan, Australia, and South America. GUND is currently run by third generation family owner Bruce Raiffe whose grandfather Jacob Swedlin purchased the company from the original founder (Adolph Gund) in 1925.<ref name="ICompanyDirect">{{cite book|last1=Grant|first1=Tina|title=International Directory of Company Histories|date=2008|publisher=St. James Press|isbn=9781558626171}}</ref>
The company is best known for its line of [[Teddy bear]]s, and holds or has held licensing agreements with companies such as [[The Walt Disney Company]], [[Sesame Street]], [[Uglydolls]], [[Boo (dog)|Boo, the World's Cutest Dog]], [[Grumpy Cat]], and [[Pusheen]]. It has won multiple awards during its 125+ years and was also the face of a [[United States Postal Service]] stamp. GUND is headquartered in [[Edison, New Jersey]] and currently a division of [[Spin Master]], which acquired the company from [[Enesco]] in March 2018.<ref>http://kidscreen.com/2018/03/05/spin-master-acquires-plush-manufacturer-gund</ref>
==History==
===1898-1925 (Formation through retirement of Adolf GUND)=== [[File:GUND_Logo_compilation.jpg|thumb|right|Progression of GUND logos from inception through 2016.]] GUND was founded in 1898 by Adolf Gund.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hoffmann|first1=Frank|last2=Augustyn|first2=Frederick J.|last3=J.|first3=Martin|title=Dictionary of Toys and Games in American Popular Culture|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135418465|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sdJEAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT117&dq=%22Jacob+Swedlin%22+%2B+GUND&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwilg_uygJzNAhUEWxoKHRnwBmkQ6AEINTAF#v=onepage&q=%22Jacob%20Swedlin%22%20%2B%20GUND&f=false|accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref> He was born in [[Germany]] and resided in [[Norwalk, Connecticut]] before settling in New York City.<ref name="AllAboutExaminer">{{cite news|last1=Meehan|first1=Meagan|title=All about GUND|accessdate=9 June 2016|publisher=The Examiner}}</ref> He started GUND as a small toy and novelty company which was incorporated under the name Gund Manufacturing Company in 1910. In the early years, GUND used GEE as the company slogan in advertising on product labels. GUND produced its first products in [[Factory|loft factories]] around New York City. It moved from location to location as it expanded, starting off on [[Third Avenue]] and eventually moving to [[List of numbered streets in Manhattan|Ninth Street]] by 1922. The moves were all prompted by the need for larger manufacturing quarters.<ref name="GUNDBook">{{cite book|last1=Raiffe|first1=Bruce S.|last2=Raiffe|first2=Alex Baron|title=GUND|date=2005|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=9780738537108}}</ref>
In the early 1900s, GUND received numerous patents that introduced various [[Mechanical toy|mechanisms]] into plush toys.<ref name="GUNDBook"/> Once such patent was for what was described as a "springing dog." The design called for a mechanism to be placed inside the stuffed animal which would cause it to jump, "bringing it to life." Another patent was for a walking mechanism which allowed the plush to walk. One of the company's most notable patents was for a "ride-on duck" which was a duck for children to ride on.<ref name="AGBRands">{{cite news|title=Gotta Getta GUND|url=http://www.americasgreatestbrands.com/volume5/pdf/gund.pdf|accessdate=9 June 2016|publisher=America's Greatest Brands}}</ref> It had wheels that operated a working duck bill which moved up and down as the wheels turned. The ride-on duck was produced by GUND for approximately 10 years commencing in 1912.<ref name="AGBRands"/> GUND also secured many other patents for toys such as the wind-up walking plush, dancing toys, and walking toys.<ref name="GUNDBook"/>
GUND created many of the industry standards in its early years, including safety standards and the manufacturing processes for toys.<ref name="AmericanToy">{{cite book|last1=Scott|first1=Sharon M.|title=Toys and American Culture: An Encyclopedia|date=2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9780313351112|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mbTUorcuXkoC&pg=PA134&dq=%22Jacob+Swedlin%22+%2B+GUND&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwilg_uygJzNAhUEWxoKHRnwBmkQ6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=%22Jacob%20Swedlin%22%20%2B%20GUND&f=false|accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref> It continued to market its products under the moniker GEE up until the late 1920s, as evidenced in various advertisements in Playthings and other toy magazines. The company was eventually sold when Adolf Gund retired in 1925.<ref name="OrlandSent">{{cite news|last1=Kovel|first1=Ralph|last2=Kovel|first2=Terry|title=Changing times|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-04-02/business/KOVEL02_1_daylight-early-clocks-patent-numbers|accessdate=9 June 2016|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|date=2 April 2006}}</ref>
===1925-1968 (New ownership and expansion)===
During the early years of the company, Adolf Gund was the mentor to Jacob Swedlin, a Russian immigrant who came to the United States in 1907.<ref name="GUNDBook"/> Gund taught Swedlin to become a cutter and pattern maker, teaching him the ins and outs of the company. When Gund retired in 1925, he sold the company to Swedlin for $1,500.<ref name="ICompanyDirect"/> Swedlin brought his brothers Abe and John on board with the company, which began rapid expansion.<ref name="AmericanToy"/> Jacob oversaw design and production, Abe acted as the chief financial officer, and John ran sales and promotions.<ref name="GUNDBook"/>
Some of the most notable GUND products in the 1930s included its line of [[Easter Bunny|Easter Bunnies]] which continue to be one of its most popular products. It also introduced "puppy purses," a stuffed animal dog that doubled as a purse. GUND also became the first licensor of cartoon characters, producing plush toy versions of [[Popeye]], [[Mickey Mouse]], [[Felix the Cat]], and [[Tigger]].<ref name="GUNDBook"/> Its relationship with The Walt Disney Company began in 1947 and contributed to expansion of GUND.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gund stuffed animals go into a museum display|url=http://stuffedparty.com/gund-stuffed-animals-go-into-a-museum-display/|accessdate=9 June 2016|publisher=Stuffed Party}}</ref> The deal with Disney allowed GUND to supply every major toy retailer in the United States with licensed Disney merchandise.<ref name="GUNDBook"/>
In the 1940s, GUND received [[Registered trademark symbol|trade mark registrations]] for two versions of its logos, both of which can be seen on its products during that time. One of the logos was a lower-case "g" with bunny ears which became synonymous with the company and its products. The popularity of the logo sparked the creation of a new plush character known as "GUNDy." GUNDy became the company mascot and grew into merchandising that included the "GUND Club."<ref name="GUNDBook"/>
During World War II in the early 1940s, GUND did not manufacture its products according to prior demand.<ref name="GUNDBook"/> To support the war effort, GUND only offered its products on a quota allotment. It also produced a doll in an army uniform as its way to encourage the purchase of war bonds. After the war, GUND began rapid expansion, releasing new products, including many new Disney characters in conjunction with the opening of Disneyland in California in 1955.<ref name="GUNDBook"/> It moved into a new manufacturing center in Brooklyn in 1957, a location that would produce its toys until 1974.<ref name="GUNDBook"/>
===1969-1990 (Further expansion & the Raiffe family)===
By 1969, GUND had become dependent on its licensing agreement with Disney for the majority of its business.<ref name="GUNDBook"/> Herbert Raiffe, the son-in-law of John Swedlin, became the company president in 1969 after Swedlin's passing.<ref name="AmericanToy"/> Raiffe began moving GUND away from its licensing agreements and shifted the focus to internal design. The company launched new products that included the "Bag Full of Laughs," a sound mechanism placed in a fabric sack and sewn into a plush.<ref>{{cite news|title=Selling Happiness - An Editorial Diary|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19701208&id=rt09AAAAIBAJ&sjid=LkgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2756,1516144&hl=en|accessdate=9 June 2016|publisher=The Glasgow Herald|date=8 December 1970}}</ref>
During the 1970s, GUND expanded its product line by releasing toys and plush popular in other countries.<ref name="GUNDBook"/> This included beanies and Gonk toys. In 1972, GUND was able to expand again thanks to [[Ling-Ling and Hsing-Hsing]], two panda bears gifted to the United States from [[China]] as part of that country's [[panda diplomacy]] efforts. The plush industry had a huge demand for panda stuffed animals, with GUND leading the way with manufacturing and distribution. Raiffe was credited by publications such as [[Forbes]] for GUND marketing efforts of the bears.<ref name="GUNDBook"/>
The 1980s brought about one of GUND's most prominent branding campaigns, known as "Gotta Getta GUND."<ref>{{cite news|title=Gund Creatures to Take First TV Bow|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mPIdAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Gotta+Getta+GUND%22&dq=%22Gotta+Getta+GUND%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi43oTYg5zNAhUOLlIKHf3ZCyEQ6AEIQTAE|accessdate=9 June 2016|publisher=Ad Week}}</ref> The campaign is credited as making GUND one of the most recognized toy companies in the United States.<ref name="AmericanToy"/> During this decade, GUND also expanded its offering of stuffed bears, releasing its collectible series of bears called the Signature Collection. Each bear was signed by the Rita Raiffe, GUND’s Director of Design and sold in limited quantities. In 1986 it released 60 new items, the most ever since the company was formed.<ref name="Higbeamplushspeaks">{{cite news|last1=Leccese|first1=Donna|title=Plush speaks a new language; electronic technology, new characters, add spark to $585 million category.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-4264283.html|accessdate=8 May 2016|publisher=Playthings|date=1 June 1986}}</ref>
===1990-2014 (100th Anniversary and postage stamp)===
In 1993, Bruce Raiffe became President of GUND.<ref name="GAAccessHB">{{cite news|last1=Weissenberger|first1=Mark|title=Meet Bruce Raiffe, president of Gund Inc., Edison, N.J.(Interview)|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-20399491.html|accessdate=8 May 2016|publisher=Gifts & Decorative Accessories|date=1 March 1998}}</ref> Prior to that time he served as the company's Marketing Director and later Vice President.<ref name="WNDHiheam">{{cite news|last1=Edelman|first1=Renee|title=Plush toys mean plush bucks|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-3871714.html|accessdate=8 May 2016|publisher=World Net Daily|date=29 July 1985}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Del Vescovo|first1=Rosemarie|title=Plush makers seek niche in crowded marketplace. (plush toys)|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-6439438.html|accessdate=8 May 2016|publisher=Playthings|date=1 June 1988}}</ref>
GUND celebrated its 100th anniversary in 1998.<ref name="HMTribnue100">{{cite news|last1=Pagan|first1=Marcos|title=Special bear gest charities $100,000|publisher=Home News Tribune|date=21 October 1998}}</ref> As part of the celebration, GUND auctioned off a 100th anniversary bear which raised $100,000 for four children's charities.<ref name="HMTribnue100"/> The bear was one-of-a-kind and purchased by Yoshihiro Sekiguchi who placed it in one of three [[Teddy bear museum]]s he owned in Japan.<ref name="HMTribnue100"/> It was the 100th anniversary of the [[Theodore Roosevelt]] "teddy bear" that brought about GUND's next milestone.<ref name="Gundstamp">{{cite news|title=GUND bear to grace new U.S. Postal Service 37-Cent stamp|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-87781362.html|accessdate=26 May 2016|publisher=Gifts & Decorative Accessories|date=1 June 2002}}</ref> In 2002, the [[United States Postal Service]] used a 1948 teddy bear of GUND to grace a 37 cent stamp in honor of the event.<ref name="Gundstamp"/>
GUND entered into a licensing agreement with [[Sesame Street]] in 2003.<ref name="HATsesame">{{cite news|title=Sesame Beginnings line to debut at JPMA|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-117115656.html|accessdate=26 May 2016|publisher=Home Accents Today|date=1 April 2004}}</ref>
===2008-present (Purchase by Enesco and beyond)===
GUND was purchased by [[Enesco]], the giftware manufacturer best known for its line of [[Precious Moments, Inc.|Precious Moments]] figurines.<ref name="EnecsoCawuicw">{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Evelyn|title=Enesco Acquires Gund Business|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1527765161.html|accessdate=26 May 2016|publisher=NJBIZ|date=7 July 2008}}</ref> GUND joined Enesco's other recently purchased brands which included [[Boyds Bears]], Our Name is Mud, philoSphie's and Jubilee Art.<ref name="EnecsoCawuicw"/> Bruce Raiffe remained with the company on a consultant type basis, but returned in 2011 when he was again appointed president of GUND.<ref name="ECupRaifePres">{{cite news|title=Enesco Appoints Bruce Raiffe President of Gund|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-249192920.html|accessdate=26 May 2016|publisher=Entertainment Close-up|date=16 February 2011}}</ref>
GUND continued to take on new licensing agreements after being purchased by Enesco. One of the most notable was that of the [[Uglydolls]] line of plush toys which it signed in 2012.<ref name="KtodaUggly">{{cite news|title=GUND signs licensing deal to make Uglydoll plush|url=http://www.kidstodayonline.com/article/405025-gund-signs-licensing-deal-to-make-uglydoll-plush|accessdate=26 May 2016|publisher=Kids Today|date=12 June 2012}}</ref> The same year it signed an agreement for ''[[Boo (dog)|Boo, the World's Cutest Dog]]''.<ref name="BloomCatCraze">{{cite news|last1=Mosendz|first1=Polly|title=How an Internet Cat Craze Became a Toy Empire|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-14/how-an-internet-cat-craze-became-a-toy-empire|accessdate=26 May 2016|publisher=Bloomberg|date=14 March 2016}}</ref> It also added ''[[Grumpy Cat]]'' in 2013 and ''[[Pusheen]]'' in 2014.<ref name="GDecorGrump">{{cite news|title=Gund Signs on for Grumpy Cat Plush|url=http://www.giftsanddec.com/article/380797-gund-signs-on-for-grumpy-cat-plush|accessdate=26 May 2016|publisher=Gifts and Dec|date=2 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="Columbian1">{{cite news|last1=Mosendz|first1=Polly|title=Internet cat craze becomes toy empire|url=http://www.columbian.com/news/2016/mar/20/internet-cat-craze-becomes-toy-empire/|accessdate=26 May 2016|publisher=The Columbian|date=20 March 2016}}</ref>
GUND went through rebranding in late 2015. It included a redesigned logo that reflects its signature plush toys. This new identity system was designed by a NYC-based digital branding agency Cynda Media Lab, and it received several national and international design awards, including 2016 Communication Arts Design Annual Award <ref>{{cite news|title=Yeh and Shin’s Cynda Media Lab Wins Communication Arts Design Award|url=http://news.fitnyc.edu/2016/09/22/yeh-and-shins-cynda-media-lab-wins-communication-arts-design-award/|accessdate=31 July 2017|publisher=FIT Newsroom|date=22 September 2016}}</ref>, 2017 HOW Logo Design Award <ref>{{cite news|title=Logo Design Awards: 8th Annual Winner Galleries|url=http://www.howdesign.com/design-creativity/8th-annual-logo-design-awards-winner-galleries/|accessdate=31 July 2017|publisher=HOW Design|date=10 February 2017}}</ref>, 2017 iF Design Award, and 2017 A'Design Award. It also released more than 200 new items as part of its 2016 campaign. It was in late 2015 that Enesco was purchased by private equity fund Balmoral Funds.<ref>{{cite news|title=Balmoral Acquires Enesco|url=http://www.giftsanddec.com/article/525620-balmoral-acquires-enesco|accessdate=9 June 2016|publisher=Gifts & Dec|date=9 November 2015}}</ref>
GUND's most recent campaign is for a charitable cause that involves "giving huggable joy to children in need," and incorporating social media with the hashtag #howdoyouhug <ref>http://gund.com/pages/history</ref>
==Products==
GUND is the manufacturer of plush stuffed animals. It sells over 1500 products including Gund, Baby Gund, Gund Bears, [[Gund Snuffles]] teddy bears, and Gund Holiday. Gund is known for under-stuffing their products to make them softer than competing teddy bears.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Muniz|first1=Betty|title=Teddy Bear Bible: The Best Things About Teddy Bears That Your Kids Will Love|date=2016|publisher=Lulu Press, Inc.|isbn=9781329824812|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XyxnCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT38&dq=%22Jacob+Swedlin%22+%2B+GUND&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwilg_uygJzNAhUEWxoKHRnwBmkQ6AEIPTAG#v=onepage&q=%22Jacob%20Swedlin%22%20%2B%20GUND&f=false|accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="AmericanToy"/> One of GUND's most popular bears is Snuffles, a plush the company launched in the 1981.<ref name="WNDHiheam"/> Snuffles was one of the first plushes to contain soft stuffing which began a trend in the industry.<ref name="WNDHiheam"/> "Snuffles has been a beloved GUND teddy bear for over 30 years, with its popular crescent moon design."<ref>http://gund.com/collections/bears/products/snuffles</ref> Some of GUND's popular products include Philbin, Peek-a-boo bear, Spunky, My First Teddy, and Sesame Street Elmo.
==Awards and recognition==
GUND has received numerous awards throughout the company history, including multiple Tillywig awards and [[American International Toy Fair]] awards.
* 2016 Tillywig Award - Sleepy Seas Soothing Turtle<ref name="Flappe">{{cite news|last1=Meehan|first1=Meagan|title=GUND winds multiple industry honors|publisher=The Examiner|date=21 January 2016}}</ref> * 2016 Top Fun Tillywig Award - Flappy the Elephant<ref name="Flappe"/> * 2016 Top Fun Tillywig Award - Rock A Bye Bear<ref name="Flappe"/> * 2015 TOBY Industry Choice Award — Big Boe * 2015 TOBY Industry Choice Award — Roswel * 2015 TOBY People’s Choice Award — Big Boe * 2014 TOBY Industry Choice Award — Cannoli Cream
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://www.gund.com/ GUND official]

The IFTA now holds separate ceremonies for the [[IFTA Film & Drama Awards]] and [[IFTA Gala Television Awards]]; before 2015 they were one ceremony known as the Irish Film & Television Awards.{{cite web | url = https://www.ifta.ie/awards/pastawards.php | title = Past Awards | publisher = Irish Film & Television Academy | location = Dublin | accessdate = 2018-03-24 }} IFTA also holds the [[John Ford Ireland]] Symposium each June and over 30 networking and learning events throughout the year.{{cite web | url = https://www.ifta.ie/academy/index.html | title = About the Academy | publisher = Irish Film & Television Academy | location = Dublin | date = 2017-10-27 | accessdate = 2018-03-24 }} IFTA also established [[John Ford Ireland]] in 2011, in association with the estate of American director [[John Ford]] and the [[Department of Culture, Heritage and the Gaeltacht]].{{cite web | url = http://www.johnfordireland.org/index.php/contact-jfi | title = About Us | accessdate = 2018-03-25 | publisher = John Ford Ireland | location = Dublin }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.ifta.ie/}} * [http://www.johnfordireland.org/ John Ford Ireland] — official site {{IFTA}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Irish Film And Television Academy}} [[Category:2003 establishments in Ireland]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2003]] [[Category:Cultural organisations based in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Entertainment in Ireland]] [[Category:Film-related professional associations]] [[Category:Film organisations in Ireland]] [[Category:Professional associations based in Ireland]] [[Category:Television in Ireland]]

{{refimprove|date=October 2016}} '''Just Buffalo Literary Center''' (JBLC) is a not-for-profit literary organization centered in [[Buffalo, NY]] which serves the greater [[Western New York]] region as a prominent literary curator. Just Buffalo Literary Center’s mission is to create and strengthen communities through the literary arts. And for more than 40 years, Just Buffalo Literary Center has brought the world’s greatest writers to Buffalo, hosted poetry events, and readings, and supported the development of young writers.
Just Buffalo Literary Center's business office is currently located above the Western New York Book Arts Center on Washington Street.
==History== ===Inception=== Just Buffalo began in 1975 when founder Debora Ott hosted a reading featuring Diane di Prima at the Allentown Community Center. In the following years, notable authors and poets such as [[Robert Creeley]], [[Ed Dorn]], [[Alice Notley]], [[Maureen Owen]], and [[Ted Berrigan]] came to Buffalo to participate in readings offered by what had by then become "Just Buffalo". The organization proceeded to host writing workshops for writers of all-ages and published a literary magazine. It also had a radio show.
===Continued growth=== In 1982, Just Buffalo Literary Center established its renowned Writers in Education program, providing in-school creative writing programs for young people. At their peak, this program served approximately 4,000 students per year. After more than two decades of stewarding community-based literary programs and establishing Just Buffalo Literary Center as a national presence on the literary scene, Debora left the organization in 1998. She hired Michael Kelleher as Artistic Director in the months before she left. Ed Taylor served as Executive Director from 1998-2001.
===2002-present=== Laurie Dean Torrell took over as Executive Director in 2002, ushering in a new era. During her tenure, Just Buffalo Literary Center has experienced an extraordinary expansion. It moved from the Tri-Main Center to the Market Arcade Building in 2005, a change which marked the beginning of a groundbreaking administrative collaboration with CEPA and Big Orbit Galleries. All three organizations benefited from this long-term effort that involves shared resources and staff as well as a joint education effort, Writing With Light. In 2016, Just Buffalo Literary Center moved from the Market Arcade Building to its current home on the second floor at the corner of Washington and Mohawk in downtown Buffalo.
Just Buffalo Literary Center's program office staff currently consists of Laurie Dean Torrell, Executive Director; Barbara Cole, Artistic Director; Noah Falck, Education Director; Kristen Pope, Development Director.
==Programs== ===BABEL===
BABEL is an international literary lecture series that brings notable authors to Buffalo to speak four times per year. It is cosponsored by [[Hallwalls]]. It was conceived of in 2006 by Michael Kelleher, who was at the time Just Buffalo's Artistic Director.<ref>{{cite web|author=Colin Dabkowski |url=http://www.buffalonews.com/entertainment/gusto/books/article808973.ece |title=The man who built Babel - Books & Poetry |publisher=The Buffalo News |date=2012-04-15 |accessdate=2012-06-22}}</ref> The series was launched in 2007. Past authors have included Nobel Prize winners [[Orhan Pamuk]], [[Derek Walcott]] and [[V.S. Naipaul]], as well as global literary icons [[Isabel Allende]], [[Amos Oz]], [[Salman Rushdie]], [[A.S. Byatt]], [[Chinua Achebe]] and many others.
BABEL was initially hosted in folk-musician [[Ani Difranco]]'s recording space, "Babeville", in the old [[Asbury Delaware United Methodist Church]], until it outgrew the space late in its second season and moved to [[Kleinhans Music Hall]].
In 2009, BABEL was awarded "Most Innovative Arts Programming (any artform)" by Buffalo Spree Magazine. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buffalospree.com/buffalospreemagazine/archives/2009_0708/070809bestofarts.html |title=Buffalo Spree Magazine |publisher=Buffalospree.com |date=1979-06-26 |accessdate=2012-06-22}}</ref>
The BABEL series has been hailed by the [[Buffalo News]] as:
:''...one of the most exciting literary series Buffalo has ever seen.'' <ref>{{cite web|author=Jeff Simon |url=http://www.buffalonews.com/entertainment/article392438.ece |title=Babel books top global writers for 2011-12 season - Entertainment |publisher=The Buffalo News |date=2011-04-14 |accessdate=2012-06-22}}</ref>
In describing BABEL in its first year, Kelleher states:
:''The idea of the series is really to bring global perspective to the literary discussion in Buffalo.''<ref>{{cite web|last=Koch |first=Peter |url=http://artvoice.com/issues/v6n36/babel |title=Babel |publisher=Artvoice.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107094054/http://artvoice.com/issues/v6n36/babel |archivedate=2012-11-07 |df= }}</ref>
From Just Buffalo Literary Center's official website:
:''BABEL lectures give the audience direct access to different parts of the world as seen through the eyes of some of the world’s most important writers. Each lecture is as unique as the writer who delivers it.'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justbuffalo.org/babel/about-babel/ |title=Just Buffalo Literary Center | About Babel |publisher=Justbuffalo.org |date= |accessdate=2012-06-22}}</ref>
BABEL is headed into its [https://buffalo.com/2016/04/23/featured/just-buffalo-announces-the-babel-literary-season-for-2016-17/ 11th season in 2017-18] and will feature [[Terry Tempest Williams]], [[Toni Morrison]], [[Viet Thanh Nguyen]], and [[Junot Diaz]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justbuffalo.org/literary-events-in-buffalo/babel-buffalo-hosts-world-famous-authors/|website=Just Buffalo|accessdate=10 August 2017|title=BABEL: Buffalo Hosts World-Famous Authors}}</ref>.
===Big Night=== Big Night is a multi-disciplinary poetry series featuring poets from around the country alongside local artists in other media such as music, film, video, and visual art. It is hosted at the Western New York Book Arts Center in downtown Buffalo.
===Writing With Light=== Writing with Light is the name for Just Buffalo's joint educational programs. In partnership with CEPA Gallery, Writing With Light offers multidisciplinary school programs such as “Picturing Poetry,” which takes a school-based, multidisciplinary approach in order to combine creative writing with photography and other art forms.
===Spotlight On Youth=== Spotlight on Youth is an open mic series open to artists aged 12-21 that meet at the Smith Theatre in [[Shea's Performing Arts Center]] six times per year.

{{Coord|40|43|12|N|73|59|18|W|display=title}} [[Image:LowerEastSideTenements.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Tenements on Ludlow Street]] [[Image:CU145Ludlow1997.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Collective: Unconscious|Collective:Unconscious Theater]] at 145 Ludlow in 1997]] [[Image:143Ludlow.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Art opening at 143 Ludlow Street in 2007]] [[Image:NYC Pickle Festival 2010 Shankbone.jpg|thumb|250px|right|2010 [[New York City]] International [[Pickled cucumber|Pickle]] Day Festival]]
'''Ludlow Street''' runs between [[Houston Street (Manhattan)|Houston]] and [[Division Street (Manhattan)|Division]] Streets on the [[Lower East Side, Manhattan|Lower East Side]] of the [[New York City]] [[borough (New York City)|borough]] of [[Manhattan]]. Vehicular traffic runs south on this [[one-way street]].
==Name== Ludlow Street was named after Lieutenant [[Augustus Ludlow]], the naval officer who was second-in-command to Captain [[James Lawrence]] on the [[USS Chesapeake (1799)|USS ''Chesapeake'']] during the ship’s engagement with [[HMS Shannon (1806)|HMS ''Shannon'']] on June 1, 1813. It was to Ludlow that Lawrence said "Don't give up the ship."<ref>{{cite streetbook}}, p.70</ref>
==History==
===Early history=== The land that is now Ludlow Street was once part of the huge De Lancey Estate,<ref name=gotham476>{{cite gotham}}, p.476</ref> which had been confiscated from James De Lancey after the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]], due to his status as a Loyalist, and auctioned off.<ref>{{cite gotham}}, pp.267-68</ref> By the early 19th century, speculative builders had constructed decent housing for workers on Ludlow Street, as well as other streets nearby, such as Eldridge, [[Forsyth Street|Forsyth]] and [[Chrystie Street|Chrystie]] Streets.<ref name=gotham476 /> At mid-century, Ludlow was in the middle of ''[[Kleindeutschland]]'', where large numbers of German-speaking immigrants had settled, and was one of the informal boundaries of the Jewish section of the neighborhood, along with [[Grand Street (Manhattan)|Grand]], [[Stanton Street|Stanton]], and Pitt Streets.<ref>{{cite gotham}}, p.745</ref>
===Art and music scene=== As far back as 1962 ''[[Theatre of Eternal Music]]'' members [[Tony Conrad]] and [[Angus MacLise]] lived and worked at 56 Ludlow<ref>Steven Watson, ''Factory Made: Warhol and the Sixties'', Pantheon, New York, 2003, p. 157</ref> and in 1965 [[Lou Reed]], [[John Cale]] and [[Sterling Morrison]] of [[The Velvet Underground]] lived and recorded there. The earliest known recorded version of ''[[All Tomorrow's Parties]]'' was recorded there.<ref>Fricke, David, liner notes for the ''Peel Slowly and See'' box set (Polydor, 1995)</ref> Other filmmakers, performers, poets, artists and musicians that lived in the building at the time included [[Warhol superstars]] [[Mario Montez]] and [[Jack Smith (film director)|Jack Smith]].<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323596204578241620759540276 "Incubator for the Velvet Underground"], ''Wall Street Journal'' (January 20, 2013)</ref> Tony Conrad has produced two CDs from the [[Jack Smith (film director)|Jack Smith]] tape archives subtitled ''56 Ludlow Street'' that were recorded at 56 Ludlow Street between 1962 and 1964.<ref>''Jack Smith - Les Evening Gowns Damnees - 56 Ludlow Street 1962-1964, Volume I'' and ''Jack Smith - Silent Shadows On Cinemaroc Island - 56 Ludlow Street 1962-1964 Volume II''. Label: Table of the Elements. CDs released in 1997</ref> In the mid-1970s Gary Weis made some short films of [[Taylor Mead]] talking to his cat in the kitchen of his Ludlow Street apartment called ''Taylor Mead's Cat''. From 1980 to the mid-80s actor/videomaker Craig Calman lived in the building adjoining Taylor Mead's.<ref>Glass, Dan [http://www.thelmagazine.com/3/11/NYCProfiles/nycprofiles.cfm "Taylor Mead, Superstar:The Life and Times of a Downtown Legend"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120914024636/http://www.thelmagazine.com/3/11/NYCProfiles/nycprofiles.cfm |date=2012-09-14 }}</ref> An excerpt from Tyler Hubby's film ''Tony Conrad: Completely in the Present'' documents Tony Conrad making a [[field recording]] on Ludlow Street.
In the early 1980s, Ludlow Street was well known as a street where [[no wave]] [[Colab]] artists connected with [[ABC No Rio]] lived; such as [[Kiki Smith]],<ref>[[Carlo McCormick]], "The Downtown Book: The New York Art Scene, 1974–1984", [[Princeton University]] Press, 2006</ref> [[Fab Five Freddy]], [[Coleen Fitzgibbon]], [[Tom Otterness]], Beatrice (Bebe) Smith, Izhar Patkin, Tron Von Hollywood, [[Wolfgang Staehle]], Raina Jane Sherry, Christof Kohlhofer, [[Carlo McCormick]], Cara Perlman, [[Steven Parrino]], Edwige Belmore, [[Joseph Nechvatal]], Uli Rimkus, [[Peter Fend]], [[Walter Robinson (art critic and artist)|Walter Robinson]], [[Aline Mare]], Emily XYZ, and [[George Condo]]. In 1980, [[Coleen Fitzgibbon]] made a video called ''Ludlow'' about Ludlow Street.<ref>[http://orensanznyc.wordpress.com/2011/09/26/les-on-the-screen-film-series-up-coming-screening-october-3-coleen-fitzgibbon-stephanie-gray/ "'LES on the Screen' Film Series: Screening October 3, 2011: Coleen Fitzgibbon & Stephanie Gray]</ref> From 1983 to 1989, the bimonthly cassette publication [[Tellus Audio Cassette Magazine]] was based out of 143 Ludlow Street. Leonard Abrams started the [[East Village Eye]] cultural magazine at 167 Ludlow Street. In 1989 the [[Beastie Boys]] used a photo of the southwest corner of Ludlow and [[Rivington Street]] as the cover for their album ''[[Paul's Boutique]]''.<ref>[http://www.gothamist.com/2006/04/19/nyc_album_art_p.php NYC Album Art: Paul's Boutique] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070415205746/http://www.gothamist.com/2006/04/19/nyc_album_art_p.php |date=2007-04-15 }}, accessed April 26, 2007. "According to the album, Paul's Boutique is in [[Brooklyn]]...but we all know this photo was taken in the [[Lower East Side]]. With a Paul's Boutique sign hanging up on the Lee's Sportswear storefront, the shot was taken at 99 Rivington Street, where Rivington and Ludlow intersect."</ref> In the 1980s, the two level loft at 58 Ludlow was the home to artists such as Alex Hahn, Douglas Eisenstark,<ref>[http://Douglaseisenstark.com Douglas Eisenstark]</ref> David Blair and Leslie Mentel, among others. Wolfgang Staehle presented an extended digital photographic record of Ludlow Street in his exhibition at [[Postmasters Gallery]] in 2016/2017.<ref>[http://brooklynrail.org/2017/02/film/Wolfgang-Staehle-Ludlow-Street Keith Sanborn art review of Wolfgang Staehle at The Brooklyn Rail]</ref>
===Gentrification=== In the mid- to late 1990s, the increasing popularity of the area among [[Hipster (contemporary subculture)|hipsters]], driven out of the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]] by an invasion of [[yuppie]]s, led to an upturn in activity along Ludlow Street, with several old establishments, such as corner delis (a.k.a. [[convenience store|bodegas)]] closing shop to make way for [[bar (establishment)|bar]]s, [[music venue]]s such as the Ludlow Street Bar & Grill (a basement restaurant and music venue), and [[Theatre|alternative theatres]] such as [[Collective: Unconscious|Collective:Unconscious Theater]] (before it became an empty lot), [[Piano's|Piano's Theater]] (before it became a music venue and bar), and Todo Con Nada (before it became The Dark Room).
In the 2000s, Ludlow Street was a destination street for musicians and music-lovers, and was heavily populated with fashion shops, art galleries, bars, restaurants, and performance venues such as [[Cake Shop NYC|Cake Shop]], [[The Living Room]], and [[Piano's]] making Ludlow into a small nightlife strip with a distinct subcultural flavor. Local institutions included the bistro/cafe Pink Pony, the adjacent artist bar Max Fish, [[Katz's Deli]] (one of the city's most famous [[delicatessen]]s) Motor City bar, Ludlow Street Guitars, Earthmatters Cafe (hangout of musicians/actors/writers/techies), Ludlow Studio (which was home to some of the top recording artists in the mid-1990s) and the Sombrero Mexican restaurant, better known to a generation of musicians as "The Hat." The art and cultural gallery Ludlow 38 is the downtown satellite for contemporary art of the [[Goethe-Institut]] New York. The space was designed by artists Ethan Breckenridge and [[Liam Gillick]]. In 2005 artist [[Wolfgang Staehle]] created ''One day of life on Ludlow Street (New York)''. The work consists of 6716 images displayed in approximately 8 second intervals over 24 hours.<ref>[http://www.evolutiondelart.net/edla/artists/w_staehle.html ''One day of life on Ludlow Street (New York)'']</ref>
In 2013, Ludlow Street between Delancey and Houston Streets lost to rising rent many small interesting shops, bars and cafes that once gave the street its distinctive flavor. Closed were: Pink Pony Cafe Littéraire & Ciné Club, the print shop at 139 Ludlow, Press Tea, Earth Matters natural food store and Motor City bar.<ref>[http://thevillager.com/2013/02/21/pink-pony-had-a-great-ride-but-couldnt-buck-changes/ The Villager: Pink Pony had a great ride, but couldn’t buck changes]</ref> However, [[Banksy]] installed a major [[street art]] installation on Ludlow Street in the fall of 2013 as part of his ''[[Better Out Than In]]'' residency: a strange vision of horses with camera-lens googles rearing up by a car covered with cowering humans. The work is Banksy’s largest New York work to date.<ref>[http://hyperallergic.com/87431/banksy-watch-new-work-in-les-red-hook-work-protected/ "Banksy Watch: New Work in LES"]</ref>
==In popular culture== * [[Suzanne Vega]]'s song, "Ludlow Street", from the 2007 album ''[[Beauty and Crime]]''. * The [[Julian Casablancas]] album ''[[Phrazes for the Young]]'' includes a song titled "Ludlow St." * The [[AaRON]] album ''Birds in the Storm'' includes a song titled ''Ludlow L'' * The [[Beastie Boys]] 1989 album ''[[Paul's Boutique]]'' features a panoramic photograph of Ludlow Street on the cover
==See also== *[[Ludlow Street Jail]] – a Federal prison which stood where [[Seward Park Campus]] is now located

{{Infobox scholar | image = Mihai Ralea.jpg | alt = | caption = Ralea at his desk, photographed c. 1960 | name = Mihai Dumitru Ralea | fullname = | other_names = Mihail Ralea, Michel Raléa, Mihai Rale | birth_date = {{birth date|1896|5|1}} | birth_place = [[Huși]], [[Kingdom of Romania]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1964|8|17|1896|5|1}} | death_place = outside [[East Berlin]], [[German Democratic Republic]] | era = 20th century | region = [[Eastern Europe]] | school_tradition = {{hlist|[[Poporanism]]|[[Structural functionalism]]|[[Marxist humanism]]}} | main_interests = [[political sociology]], [[sociology of culture]], [[aesthetics]], [[anthropology]], [[social psychology]], [[national psychology]], [[social pedagogy]], [[Marxist sociology]], [[Romanian literature]] | notable_ideas = | major_works = | influences = [[Henri Bergson]], [[Célestin Bouglé]], [[Émile Durkheim]], [[Friedrich Engels]], [[Paul Fauconnet]], [[Ludwig Gumplowicz]], [[Dimitrie Gusti]], [[Lucien Herr]], [[Garabet Ibrăileanu]], [[Pierre Janet]], [[Jean Jaurès]], [[Ludwig Klages]], [[Vladimir Lenin]], [[Lucien Lévy-Bruhl]], [[André Malraux]], [[Karl Marx]], [[Max Scheler]], [[Werner Sombart]], [[Joseph Stalin]] | influenced = [[Matei Călinescu]], [[Adrian Marino]], [[Tatiana Slama-Cazacu]], [[D. I. Suchianu]] }}
'''Mihai Dumitru Ralea''' (also known as '''Mihail Ralea''', '''Michel Raléa''', or '''Mihai Rale''';<ref name="mstr586">Straje, p. 586</ref> May 1, 1896 – August 17, 1964) was a [[Romania]]n social scientist, cultural journalist, and political figure. He debuted as an affiliate of [[Poporanism]], the left-wing [[Agrarianism|agrarian]] movement, which he infused with influences from [[corporatism]] and [[Marxism]]. A distinguished product of French academia, Ralea rejected traditionalism and welcomed cultural modernization, outlining the program for a secular and democratic "peasant state". His ideology blended into his scholarly work, with noted contributions to [[political sociology]], the [[sociology of culture]], and [[Social psychology|social]] and [[national psychology]]. He was a professor at the [[University of Iași]] and, from 1938, the [[University of Bucharest]].
By 1935, Ralea had become a doctrinaire of the [[National Peasants' Party]], managing ''[[Viața Românească]]'' review and ''[[Dreptatea]]'' daily. He had publicized polemics with the far-right circles and [[Fascism|fascist]] [[Iron Guard]], which he denounced as alien to the Romanian ethos. He later drifted apart from the party's centrist leadership and his own democratic ideology, setting up a [[Socialist Peasants' Party]], then embracing authoritarian politics. He was a founding member and [[Ministry of Labor, Family, and Social Protection (Romania)|Labor Minister]] of the dictatorial [[National Renaissance Front]], representing its corporatist left-wing. He fell from power in 1940, finding himself harassed by successive fascist regimes, and became a "[[fellow traveler]]" of the underground [[Romanian Communist Party|Communist Party]].
Ralea willingly cooperated with the communists and the [[Ploughmen's Front]] before and after their arrival to power, serving as [[Ministry of Culture and National Patrimony|Minister of Arts]], [[List of Ambassadors from Romania to the United States|Ambassador to the United States]], and vice president of the [[Great National Assembly]]. He was sidelined, then recovered, by the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]], and, as a [[Marxist humanism|Marxist humanist]], was one of its leading cultural ambassadors by 1960. Heavily controlled by [[Censorship in Communist Romania|communist censorship]], his work gave scientific credentials to the regime's [[Anti-Americanism|anti-American]] propaganda, though Ralea also used his position to protect some of those persecuted by the authorities.
Ralea's final contributions assisted in the re-professionalization of Romanian psychology and education, with the retention of a more liberal communist doctrine. Always an avid traveler and raconteur, he died abroad, while on mission to the [[UNESCO]]. He endures in cultural memory as a controversial figure. He is celebrated for his sociological and critical insights, but reprehended for his nepotism, his political choices, and his literary compromises. His only, and last, direct descendant was a daughter, Catinca Ralea, who achieved literary fame as a translator of Western literature.
==Biography==
===Early life and Poporanist beginnings=== A native of [[Huși]], [[Fălciu County]] (currently in [[Vaslui County]]), Ralea was the son of a Dumitru Ralea, a local magistrate, and Ecaterina Botezatu-Ralea.<ref name="gc912">Călinescu, p. 912</ref> According to historian Camelia Zavarache, Ralea's ethnic background was non-Romanian: on his father's side, he was a [[Bulgarians in Romania|Bulgarian]], while his mother was [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish]].<ref>Zavarache, pp. 196–197. See also Moldovan, p. 115</ref> The family was relatively wealthy, and Dumitru had served as Fălciu representative in the [[Senate of Romania]].<ref>Zavarache, p. 187</ref> His son was always spiritually attached to his native region and, later in life, bought himself a vineyard on Dobrina Hill, just outside Huși, building himself a vacation home.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 125; (2010), p. 385; Zavarache, p. 189</ref> Huși was where he completed his primary education, before he moved on to the urban center of [[Iași]], where he enlisted at [[boarding school]] (''Liceul Internat'').<ref>Călinescu, p. 912; Vianu, p. 143; Zavarache, pp. 197–198, 199</ref> He was colleagues with another future sociologist, [[D. I. Suchianu]]. The two remained personal and political friends for the rest of their lives.<ref name="ln(10)129">Nastasă (2010), p. 129</ref> Another enduring friendship was formed on school grounds between Ralea and historian [[Petre Constantinescu-Iași]], who became Ralea's main connection to the revolutionary left.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 197–198, 199, 238</ref>
Ralea went on to attend the [[University of Bucharest]] Faculty of Letters and Philosophy, under [[Constantin Rădulescu-Motru]] (who shortlisted and prepared Ralea for academic tenure).<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 191–192, 293, 344</ref> He made his debut in publishing during 1916, with an essay in Rădulescu-Motru's ''Revista de Filozofie'',<ref name="tv144">Vianu, p. 144</ref> and with ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'' articles that he usually signed with the initials ''M. R.'' (an alternative signature he would use for the rest of his career).<ref>Straje, pp. 406, 586</ref> Ralea was university colleagues with philosophers [[Tudor Vianu]] and [[Nicolae Bagdasar]], with whom he remained close friends for the rest of his life.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 283. See also Vianu, p. 143</ref> Their studies were interrupted by the [[Romania in World War I|Romanian Campaign of World War I]], during which time Ralea relocated to Iași. He took his final examination in Law and Letters at the [[University of Iași]], in 1918.<ref name="gc912"/> His professors included the culture critic [[Garabet Ibrăileanu]], who became Ralea's mentor.<ref name="zavr187–188">Zavarache, pp. 187–188</ref> Ralea recalled that his first encounter with Ibrăileanu was "my life's greatest intellectual event".<ref>Vianu, p. 145</ref>
Described by Vianu as a "young luminary" with "new and original ideas", "always surrounded by a sizable pack of students",<ref>Vianu, p. 143</ref> Ralea returned to cultural journalism in postwar [[Greater Romania]]. From February 1919, he was a contributor to the Iași-based review ''Însemnări Literare'', which stood in for the temporarily disestablished ''[[Viața Românească]]''.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 114; Nicolescu, p. 131. See also Desa ''et al.'' (1987), pp. 508–509</ref> The magazine was managed by the novelist [[Mihail Sadoveanu]] and heavily influenced by Ibrăileanu. Their friendship sealed Ralea's affiliation to prewar [[Poporanism]], a leftist current which promoted [[agrarianism]], "national specificity", and art with a social mission. The ''Însemnări Literare'' group also recognized that Poporanism was made inadequate by the social promises of [[Land reform in Romania|land reform]] and [[universal male suffrage]]. These policies, Ibrăileanu acknowledged, "settled a debt" with the peasantry.<ref>Nicolescu, p. 132</ref> Poporanism was generally pro-[[Westernization]], with a noted reserve; taken separately, Ralea was the most pro-Western, socialist, and least culturally conservative thinker of this category.<ref>Balázs Trencsényi, "Conceptualizarea caracterului național în tradiția intelectuală românească", in Neumann & Heinen, pp. 353–354; Verdery, pp. 50–51, 53, 328</ref>
Also in 1919, Ralea and his new friend, [[Andrei Oțetea]], earned state scholarships to complete his doctorate in Paris.<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 190–192, 250, 284</ref> Ralea entered the [[École Normale Supérieure]] as a disciple of [[Lucien Herr]],<ref name="tv144"/> simultaneously registering for doctoral programs in letters and politics, with interests in sociology and psychology. He studied under the [[Structural functionalism|functionalist]] [[Célestin Bouglé]], then under [[Paul Fauconnet]] and [[Lucien Lévy-Bruhl]], and later, at the [[Collège de France]], under [[Pierre Janet]].<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 191–192, 293</ref> As he himself recounted, he became a passionate follower of the [[French Left]], a reader of [[Jean Jaurès]], and a guest of [[Léon Blum]]'s.<ref name="istnm28">Stanomir, p. 28</ref> He defined himself as a [[Rationalism|rationalist]], heir to the [[Age of Enlightenment]] and the [[French Revolution]],<ref name="istnm28"/> and was ostensibly an [[Atheism|atheist]].<ref>Nastasă (2010), p. 422</ref> Ralea's secular agenda was underscored when he joined the [[Freemasonry in Romania|Romanian Freemasonry]], which, historian Lucian Nastasă writes, implied a commitment to [[freethought]] and religious toleration.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 102</ref>
For a while, Ralea managed a Romanian restaurant owned by the banker [[Aristide Blank]].<ref>Nastasă (2010), p. 32</ref> He was part of a tight cell of Romanian students in letters or history, which also included Oțetea, [[Gheorghe Brătianu]], and [[Alexandru Rosetti]], who remained close friends over the decades.<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 250, 284, 293, 345–347</ref> Suchianu and his sister Ioana, who were also studying in Paris, lived in the same boarding house as Ralea.<ref name="ln(10)129"/>
===Debut as theoretician=== With funds raised by a Support Committee that included Ralea,<ref>Ilie Th. Riga, Gheorghe Călin, ''Dr. Fr. I. Rainer'', [[Editura Științifică]], Bucharest, 1966, p. 62</ref> ''Viața Românească'' was eventually revived by Ibrăileanu. Ralea became its foreign correspondent, sending in articles about the intellectual life and philosophical doctrines of the [[French Third Republic|Third Republic]],<ref name="ln(09)192">Nastasă (2007), p. 192</ref> and possibly the first Romanian notices about the work of [[Marcel Proust]].<ref name="ccproust">{{ro icon}} Constantin Coroiu, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/COROIUoct12.htm "Proust și romanul românesc modern"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', October 2012</ref> He traveled extensively, studying first-hand the cultural life of France, Belgium, Italy, and [[Weimar Republic|Weimar Germany]].<ref name="ln(09)192"/>
In 1922, Ralea took his ''[[Habilitation|Docteur d'État]]'' degree (the sixth Romanian to ever qualify for it)<ref name="ln(09)192"/> with ''L'idée de la révolution dans les doctrines socialistes'' ("The Idea of Revolution in Socialist Doctrines"). Under the [[Francization|Francized]] name ''Michel Raléa'', he published it at Rivière company in 1923. ''L'idée de la révolution...'' theorized that, in order to be classified as a revolution, a social movement needed at once a "social body", an "ideal", and a "transfer of power"—depending on which trait was prevailing, revolutions were, respectively, "organic", "programmatic", or "means-based".<ref>Herseni, p. 546</ref> The focus of his attention was [[Pierre-Joseph Proudhon]], whom he rediscovered (and criticized) as a proponent of "class solidarity" and [[nonviolent revolution]].<ref>Ghiață, pp. 101–102</ref> The work earned Ralea the [[Institut de France]]'s [[Prix Osiris]]<ref name="tv144"/> and a [[Doctor of Letters]] degree in 1923.<ref name="gc912"/> He spent another several months frequenting [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Berlin University]] lectures.<ref name="ln(09)192"/> It was there that he first met a future enemy, the poet-mathematician [[Ion Barbu]]. The latter left a corrosive record of their first encounter, dismissing Ralea as a "clown" with "aristocratic manias".<ref>Nastasă (2010), p. 226</ref>
Upon his return to Romania, Ralea began publishing his political and sociological essays in reviews such as ''Fapta'', ''[[Ideea Europeană]]'', and ''[[Gândirea]]''.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 76; Desa ''et al.'' (1987), p. 469; Straje, p. 586</ref> He was also involved with [[Dimitrie Gusti]] and [[Virgil Madgearu]]'s Romanian Social Institute, publishing his texts in its ''Arhiva pentru Știință și Reformă Socială''. In 1923, it hosted his essay on "The Issue of Societal Classification" and his critical review of German sociology.<ref>Gusti, pp. 16, 17</ref> While still in Paris, Ralea was confident that he would find employment: the University of Iași Chair of Sociology had been set aside for him by Rădulescu-Motru, with Ibrăileanu's approval.<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 293, 344</ref> The matter was complicated when another Paris graduate, [[Garabet Aslan]], ran for the same position. Supported by Ibrăileanu and Gusti, Ralea was eventually moved to the Logic and Modern Philosophy Department, as an assistant professor to [[Ion Petrovici]], while also employed as lecturer in [[social pedagogy]].<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 344–345, 347, 483</ref> According to Ralea's own words, this was a "ridiculous" situation: most of his students were girls, some of whom were infatuated with him.<ref name="ln(09)483">Nastasă (2007), p. 483</ref> He had married Ioana Suchianu in November 1923, while still in Bucharest, and lived with her in a small apartment above the ''Viața Românească'' offices.<ref>Nastasă (2010), pp. 150, 200–201, 266</ref>
For the next two years, Ralea diversified his qualifications with the goal of obtaining employment in his main field. He published the tract ''Formația ideii de personalitate'' ("How the Notion of Personality Is Formed"), noted as a pioneering introduction to [[behavioural genetics]].<ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 345</ref> On January 1, 1926, following good referrals from Petrovici (and despite the preference of psychology students, who favored C. Fedeleș), Ralea was appointed Professor of Psychology and Aesthetics at Iași University.<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 345–346, 347, 374</ref>
Ralea soon became one of ''Viața Românească''{{'}}s ideologues and polemicists, as well as architect of its satire column, ''Miscellanea'' (alongside Suchianu and, initially, [[George Topîrceanu]]).<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 135</ref> By 1925, he was also regularly featured in the left-wing daily ''[[Adevărul]]'', and its cultural supplement, ''[[Adevărul Literar și Artistic]]''.<ref>Desa ''et al.'' (2003), pp. 17, 18</ref> His essays were taken up by other cultural magazines throughout Romania, including ''[[Kalende]]'' of [[Pitești]] and ''Minerva'' of Iași.<ref>Desa ''et al.'' (2003), pp. 557, 619–620</ref> In 1927, when Ralea published his ''Contribuțiuni la știința societății'' ("Contributions to Social Science") and ''Introducere în sociologie'' ("Companion to Sociology"),<ref>Călinescu, p. 1025; Herseni, p. 542</ref> Gusti's Social Institute had Ralea as a guest speaker, with a lecture on "Social Education".<ref>Gusti, p. 93</ref> At around that time, with Gusti as president of the [[Romanian Radio Broadcasting Company|Broadcasting Company]], Ralea became a frequent presence on the radio.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 523</ref>
In his columns and essays, Ralea defended Ibrăileanu's "national specificity" against criticism from the new-wave [[Literary modernism|modernists]] at ''[[Sburătorul]]''. [[Eugen Lovinescu]], the modernist ideologue, had reconnected with 19th-century [[classical liberalism]], rejecting Poporanism as a nationalist, culturally isolationist, and [[Socialization (economics)|socializing]] phenomenon. Lovinescu and Ralea denounced each other's politics as [[reactionary]].<ref>Crohmălniceanu, pp. 39, 128, 133; E. Lovinescu, pp. 116–119</ref> Ralea opined that Poporanist ideas were still culturally relevant, and not in fact isolationist, since they provided a recipe for "originality"; as he put it, "national specificity" had become inevitable.<ref>Nicolescu, p. 85</ref> The conflict was not just political: Ralea also objected to modernist aesthetics, from the pure poetry cultivated by ''Sburătorul'' to the more radical [[Constructivism (art)|Constructivism]] of ''[[Contimporanul]]'' magazine.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, pp. 123–124, 128, 133–135, 140</ref>
Ralea was not an anti-modernist, but rather a particular modernist. According to his friend and colleague [[Octav Botez]], he was an "integrally modern man" in tastes and behavior, "one of the few philosophers who conceived of, and lived, their lives as regular people, with a naturalness and facility that were charming and stimulating."<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 483–484</ref> The same was also noted by ''Contimporanul'' writer [[Sergiu Dan]], who proposed that Ralea denied himself "all sort of transaction with the confuse world of sentiment".<ref name="sdan184">Dan, p. 184</ref>
Ralea's literary columns very often promoted modernist writers, or modernist interpretations of classical ones, such as when he used Janet's psychology to explain the genesis of works by [[Thomas Hardy]].<ref>Călinescu, p. 911; Vianu, p. 150</ref> More famous was his reading of Proust through [[Henri Bergson]]'s [[Matter and Memory|classification of memory]].<ref name="ccproust"/><ref name="gc911">Călinescu, p. 911</ref> Ralea offered much praise to rationalist modernists such as [[Alexandru A. Philippide]], and hailed [[Tudor Arghezi]], the eclectic modernizer of poetic language, as Romania's greatest poet of the day.<ref>Constantinescu, p. 227; Crohmălniceanu, p. 140. See also M. Lovinescu, p. 42</ref> Ralea (and, before him, Ibrăileanu) campaigned for [[social realism]] in prose.
